attribute.source_of_outbreak: A specific food item has not yet been identified as the source of this outbreak. However, CDC is concerned that several recent illnesses have been reported. Listeria illness is rare, but it can result in serious illness or death.
attribute.control_measures:
Take steps to prevent getting sick from Listeria 

Follow CDC on Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter for updates about this outbreak.
Learn which foods are more likely to contain Listeria and ways to prevent getting Listeria.
Stay up-to-date on food recalls and outbreaks.

attribute.source_of_outbreak: Clinicians: Please report any carbapenem-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (CRPA) from an ocular specimen or VIM-CRPA from any specimen source with collection dates since January 1, 2022, to your local or state health department’s healthcare-associated infections contact or email haioutbreak@cdc.gov for assistance submitting specimens. Ask your clinical laboratories to save these isolates for further characterization at public health laboratories.

events.event_type: Multistate Norovirus Outbreak Linked to Raw Oysters from Texas

attribute.location: Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Tennessee, Texas
attribute.source_of_outbreak: State and local officials have collected information about the source of oysters from restaurants where sick people ate. FDA has confirmed that potentially contaminated raw oysters were harvested in area TX 1, Galveston Bay, Texas. The FDA and the states are conducting a trace forward investigation to determine where the raw oysters were distributed and to ensure they’re removed from the food supply.

attribute.control_measures:
Keep raw enoki mushrooms separate from foods that won’t be cooked.

This prevents the spread of Listeria germs from enoki mushrooms to foods that you won’t cook before eating.

attribute.source_of_outbreak: Deli meats (cold cuts, lunch meats, hot dogs, and pâtés sold at the deli) and cheeses are known sources of Listeria illnesses. This is because Listeria can easily spread among food on deli countertops, deli slicers, surfaces, and hands. Listeria is a hardy germ that can be difficult to fully remove once it is in the deli. It can survive and grow at cold temperatures in the refrigerator.

events.event_type: Outbreak of Lung Injury Associated with the Use of E-Cigarette, or Vaping, Products

attribute.location: Alabama, Alaska, California, Connecticut, Delaware, District Of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Puerto Rico, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virgin Islands, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia
attribute.source_of_outbreak: For more information and resources for key stakeholders, visit For Healthcare Providers and For State and Local Health Departments. General resources are also available.

attribute.location: Arizona, California, District Of Columbia, Florida, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Tennessee, Washington
Alaska, California, Hawaii, Kentucky, Michigan, Utah
attribute.control_measures:
The following groups are at highest risk for acquiring HAV infection or developing serious complications from HAV infection in these outbreaks and should be offered the hepatitis A vaccine in order to prevent or control an outbreak:

People who use drugs (injection or non-injection)
People experiencing unstable housing or homelessness 
Men who have sex with men (MSM)
People who are currently or were recently incarcerated 
People with chronic liver disease, including cirrhosis, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C
